prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
Our goal is to map the specified LIRG in CO (3-2), HCO+ (4-3), SiO and CH3OH. A total CO (3-2) flux and line width from the JCMT are available in the literature (43.8 K km/s and 479 km/s; Leech et al. 2010). If the gas distribution we are probing with ALMA is clumpy (i.e. divided into ten pieces) and we desire a signal-to-noise of 6, our sensitivity requirement is an rms of 22.5 mJy. There are also single-dish measurements of the CO (1-0) flux for this LIRG (142.0 Jy km/s and w~400 km/s; Mirabel et al. 1990). For a sample of nearby U/LIRGs, Wilson et al. (2008) found ratios of HCO+ (4-3)/CO (1-0) of ~0.1-0.2 which conservatively translates to a sensitivity requirement of 2.8 mJy for detecting the HCO+ (4-3) line at a signal-to-noise of 6 for multiple (2) clumps. Both observations (Meier \& Turner 2012) and simulations (Meijerink \& Israel 2007) of SiO in nearby galaxies suggest SiO (1-0)/CO (1-0)} ~0.05-0.1, as well as an agreement within the SiO and methanol lines (at a given transition) within an order of magnitude. Thus we expect both the SiO and CH3OH fluxes to be on the order of half of that of HCO+ J=4-3 and thus easily detected.
To enable a comparison of the distribution of the molecular gas as revealed by ALMA to star clusters seen in our existing HST imaging, we require spatial resolutions of 0.15". At 6506 km/s, the LIRG disk does not appear extended beyond the largest recoverable angular scale and we do not require the ACA.
SiO and CH3OH lines have been observed in other galaxies (Meier & Turner 2012; Topal et al. 2013) with linewidths as low as 15 km/s, so we require 5 km/s spectral resolution to Nyquist sample the line.

Our goal is to map the specified LIRG in CO (3-2), HCO+ (4-3), SiO and CH3OH. No CO (3-2) fluxes are available in the literature, so we use the published CO (1-0) flux and line width (46.5 Jy km/s, w~80 km/s; Mirabel et al. 1990) and an average conversion ratio quoted for LIRGs of R31~0.5 (Leech et al. 2010; Papadapolous et al. 2008), to estimate total CO J=3-2 flux. Assuming a Gaussian line, we expect peak fluxes of 2.47 Jy for CO (3-2).
If the gas distribution we are probing with ALMA is clumpy (i.e. divided into ten pieces) and we desire a signal-to-noise of 6, our sensitivity requirement is an rms of 41.2 mJy. For a sample of nearby U/LIRGs, Wilson et al. (2008) found ratios of HCO+ (4-3)/CO (1-0) of ~0.1-0.2 which conservatively translates to a sensitivity requirement of 3.1 mJy for detecting the HCO+ (4-3) line at a signal-to-noise of 6 for multiple (3) clumps. Both observations (Meier \& Turner 2012) and simulations (Meijerink \& Israel 2007) of SiO in nearby galaxies suggest SiO (1-0)/CO (1-0)} ~0.05-0.1, as well as an agreement within the SiO and methanol lines (at a given transition) within an order of magnitude. Thus we expect both the SiO and CH3OH fluxes to be on the order of half of that of HCO+ J=4-3 and thus easily detected.
To enable a comparison of the distribution of the molecular gas as revealed by ALMA to star clusters seen in our existing HST imaging, we require spatial resolutions of 0.15". At 14,464 km/s, the LIRG disk does not appear extended beyond the largest recoverable angular scale and we do not require the ACA.
SiO and CH3OH lines have been observed in other galaxies (Meier & Turner 2012; Topal et al. 2013) with linewidths as low as 15 km/s, so we require 5 km/s spectral resolution to Nyquist sample the line.

Our goal is to map the specified LIRG in CO (3-2), HCO+ (4-3), SiO and CH3OH. No CO (3-2) fluxes are available in the literature, so we use the published CO (1-0) flux and line width (118.1 Jy km/s, w~110 km/s; Baan et al. 2008) and an average conversion ratio quoted for LIRGs of R31~0.5 (Leech et al. 2010; Papadapolous et al. 2008), to estimate total CO J=3-2 flux. Assuming a Gaussian line, we expect peak fluxes of 4.56mJy for CO (3-2).
If the gas distribution we are probing with ALMA is clumpy (i.e. divided into ten pieces) and we desire a signal-to-noise of 6, our sensitivity requirement is an rms of 76 mJy. For a sample of nearby U/LIRGs, Wilson et al. (2008) found ratios of HCO+ (4-3)/CO (1-0) of ~0.1-0.2 which conservatively translates to a sensitivity requirement of 3.3 mJy for detecting the HCO+ (4-3) line at a signal-to-noise of 6 for multiple (5) clumps. Both observations (Meier \& Turner 2012) and simulations (Meijerink \& Israel 2007) of SiO in nearby galaxies suggest SiO (1-0)/CO (1-0)} ~0.05-0.1, as well as an agreement within the SiO and methanol lines (at a given transition) within an order of magnitude. Thus we expect both the SiO and CH3OH fluxes to be on the order of half of that of HCO+ J=4-3 and thus easily detected.
To enable a comparison of the distribution of the molecular gas as revealed by ALMA to star clusters seen in our existing HST imaging, we require spatial resolutions of 0.15". At 8098 km/s, the LIRG disk does not appear extended beyond the largest recoverable angular scale and we do not require the ACA.
SiO and CH3OH lines have been observed in other galaxies (Meier & Turner 2012; Topal et al. 2013) with linewidths as low as 15 km/s, so we require 5 km/s spectral resolution to Nyquist sample the line.

Our goal is to map the specified LIRG in CO (3-2), HCO+ (4-3), SiO and CH3OH. No CO (3-2) fluxes are available in the literature, so we use the published CO (1-0) flux and line width (5.9 K km/s, w~259 km/s; Sanders et al. 1991) and an average conversion ratio quoted for LIRGs of R31~0.5 (Leech et al. 2010; Papadapolous et al. 2008), to estimate total CO J=3-2 flux. Assuming a Gaussian line, we expect peak fluxes of 3.5mJy for CO (3-2).
If the gas distribution we are probing with ALMA is clumpy (i.e. divided into ten pieces) and we desire a signal-to-noise of 6, our sensitivity requirement is an rms of 58.3 mJy. For a sample of nearby U/LIRGs, Wilson et al. (2008) found ratios of HCO+ (4-3)/CO (1-0) of ~0.1-0.2 which conservatively translates to a sensitivity requirement of 2.6 mJy for detecting the HCO+ (4-3) line at a signal-to-noise of 6 for multiple (5) clumps. Both observations (Meier \& Turner 2012) and simulations (Meijerink \& Israel 2007) of SiO in nearby galaxies suggest SiO (1-0)/CO (1-0)} ~0.05-0.1, as well as an agreement within the SiO and methanol lines (at a given transition) within an order of magnitude. Thus we expect both the SiO and CH3OH fluxes to be on the order of half of that of HCO+ J=4-3 and thus easily detected.
To enable a comparison of the distribution of the molecular gas as revealed by ALMA to star clusters seen in our existing HST imaging, we require spatial resolutions of 0.15". At 7328 km/s, the LIRG disk does not appear extended beyond the largest recoverable angular scale and we do not require the ACA.
SiO and CH3OH lines have been observed in other galaxies (Meier & Turner 2012; Topal et al. 2013) with linewidths as low as 15 km/s, so we require 5 km/s spectral resolution to Nyquist sample the line.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: Local luminous infrared galaxies are dust-enshrouded, molecular gas-rich, intense starbursts that are usually inspired by major mergers. LIRGs thus provide an ideal place for an in depth look at the affects of mergers on the interstellar medium (ISM), specifically feedback from merger-driven star formation in the form of shocks. We select a sample of LIRGs that have a so-far unexplained excess of warm molecular hydrogen as revealed by Spitzer mid-IR spectroscopy. The IR data suffer from poor spatial and spectral resolution while optical observations have difficulty probing the dense and dusty ISM. ALMA provides the best tool for uncovering shocks in these dusty starbursts and for probing the shock chemistry to determine the extent, power, and dynamics of the shocked molecular gas. We propose to map these excess H2 emitters with dense molecular gas tracers CO and HCO+ to look for evidence of shocks/outflows and to determine the scale of their contribution to heating the ISM. We will also map the shock tracers SiO and methanol (CH3OH) to diagnose the strenghth, speed, and kinematics of any observed shocks and ultimately to determine the source of the shock.
prp:ObsProposal.prp:keyword: Luminous and Ultra-Luminous Infra-Red Galaxies (LIRG & ULIRG)

prp:PrincipalInvestigator.prp:organisation: Department of Astronomy, Virginia, University of
